questions.question_text: Which two protocols are supported on Expressway Zones? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
Cisco Expressway Zones are used to define communication boundaries for different protocols and services in the Expressway network. These zones determine how traffic is routed between different networks, allowing the system to manage different types of communication traffic and control access to resources.

The two protocols supported on Expressway Zones are:

SIP (Session Initiation Protocol):

SIP is a signaling protocol widely used for establishing, maintaining, and terminating real-time sessions, such as voice and video calls. Expressway supports SIP for interconnecting different parts of the network, such as connecting users to remote services or external users.
H.323:

H.323 is a signaling and control protocol used for multimedia communications, especially in video conferencing. Cisco Expressway also supports H.323 for interconnecting with H.323-based endpoints and networks.

Selected Answer: AB
Proper DNS configuration on Expressway servers is critical for:
Verifying the common name in server certificates (A)
Routing calls based on SIP URI (B)

Selected Answer: BC
This is a tricky question. The real trick on this is what requires a FQDN.

A. Expressway servers verify the common name attribute in server certificates.
I am leaning away from this one. The common name doesnt necessarily have to line up with a FQDN. 

B. Expressway servers route calls based on SIP URI.
This is a definite yes. URI dialing requires a DNS server to be configured.

C. Admins avoid IP address configuration for neighbor zone peers.
I am leaning towards this one. You can only configure an IP address or FQDN. If you go FQDN, you need a DNS configured

D. Expressway servers use NTP peer authentication for secure time updates.
You can configure an IP address or FQDN here. I am discounting this because you can configure an IP address.

E. Admins download software updates from the Cisco website via WebUI.
Software updates are not obtained via WebUI for expressways. I was under the assumption that WebUI is only for select routers.

choices.D: Expressway servers use NTP peer authentication for secure time updates.
choices.B: Expressway servers route calls based on SIP URI.
choices.A: Expressway servers verify the common name attribute in server certificates.
choices.E: Admins download software updates from the Cisco website via WebUI.
choices.C: Admins avoid IP address configuration for neighbor zone peers.

questions.question_text: Which two scenarios need a proper DNS configuration on Expressway servers? (Choose two.)

A collaboration engineer is configuring Cisco Webex Edge for video conferencing devices to provide support for Cisco Webex Control Hub configuration management. Which configuration control mode must be set on Cisco UCM for Control Hub to manage the on-premises device configuration?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Understanding the Control Modes:
Unified CM and Endpoint (Default): This mode allows both the UCM and the endpoint to act as a multi-master source for provisioning endpoint data.
Unified CM: In this mode, the UCM is the sole source for provisioning endpoint data.
Endpoint: In this mode, the endpoint is the sole source for provisioning endpoint data. 

Webex Edge only - not present in CUCM

Webex Device Connector, lets you link Webex Edge to Control hub and provision the device settings.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KzklR87dctM

Correct Answer:
C. Cisco UCM and endpoint
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/cucm/admin/12_5_1SU1/cucm_b_feature-configuration-guide-for-cisco1251SU1/cucm_b_feature-configuration-guide-for-cisco1251SU1_chapter_01001110.html#concept_C0E4C23CABAAE36BD305ED334A1A0F16

Selected Answer: C
Def NOT A, as WebEx Edge Only is not even an option in UCM. 
Not B, Endpoint only, as that would only give CHub Read Access.
Not D, as that would give CHub NO access.

C allows CM to pull the config from the endpoint after CHub pushed a config to the endpoint. View this whitepaper - webex-edge-devices-white-paper.pdf

Selected Answer: A
Answer A: When configuring Cisco Webex Edge for video conferencing devices to be managed by Cisco Webex Control Hub, the configuration control mode on Cisco UCM (Unified Communications Manager) must be set to Webex Edge only.

This setting ensures that the Webex Control Hub can manage the on-premises video endpoints via Webex Edge, while Cisco UCM handles the call routing and call control. In this setup, Webex Control Hub takes responsibility for the configuration management of video devices, including updates and settings, via the Webex Edge platform, which provides secure connectivity to the cloud.

comments.content: WebEx Edge Only is not an option
Control Hub can manage configurations, but they will appear as read-only in UCM.

choices.A: The endpoints can use a Cisco router API to disable NAT temporarily.
choices.C: Cisco access protocol can make a direct path between endpoints on an internal network.
choices.B: Cisco Mobile and Remote Access allows for media traffic directly between two internal endpoints.
choices.D: STUN makes UDP connections through NAT devices.

questions.question_text: Which technique can be used to have media flow directly between two endpoints that have a NAT between them?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Correct Answer:
D. STUN makes UDP connections through NAT devices.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/solutions/CVD/Campus/cisco-sda-design-guide.html

choices.D: The FQDN of Expressway-E cannot be resolved by the DNS server.
choices.E: The traversal zone TLS verify subject name in Expressway-E does not match the FQDN of Expressway-C.
choices.C: The communication port is not set to 7001.
choices.B: The peer 1 address in Expressway-C is not the FADN of Expressway-E.
choices.A: The peer 1 address in Expressway-C must be replaced by the FQDN of Expressway-C.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer must configure a B2B traversal zone. Trusted certification authority and server certificates are uploaded to Cisco Expressway-C and Expressway-E servers. After the traversal zone configuration is completed in Expressway-C, the error message in the exhibit appears. What are the two reasons for the error? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
Will go with B and E. 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/expressway/config_guide/X14-0/basic_config/exwy_b_cisco-expressway-e-and-expressway-c-basic-configuration-deployment-guide-x14-0/exwy_m_routing-configuration.html#concept_5CACB904BBC11E766FDB34D20BE12C9A

Selected Answer: BE
A is wrong because the FQDN of Expressway-E should be used in the peer address field.
B is correct, assuming "FADN" is just a typo. 
C is not an issue, you don't necessarily need to start by using 7001. As long as E is listening on 7002, this works (tested in the lab).
D does not apply here because they're not using the FQDN currently.
E makes sense, they're not showing the config on the E side, but if you put the wrong "TLS verify subject name" there you will get a TLS connection failure.

Going for B and E here.

I am leaning more towards B and C on this one.
Literally answers A and B are contradictory to each other.
Unless this setup has multiple traversal zones, and this isnt the first one, they should be using port 7001.
